abstract.text: A FTER more than a century and a half of investigation of the ruin there still remains much to be done, both in excavation and in the int what has been excavated. The state of knowledge which had been reac was admirably summarised by the late Professor August Mau. Since t the last edition of his work l there has begun a new era, characterise systematic and capable excavation of the eastern part of the Strada d Della Corte's thorough study of the widely scattered information concerni of the various houses ', and Spano's illuminating interpretation of the artistic remains in the light of the social and aesthetic traditions of the H

Although the artistic quality of the objects from this site, at least in th and with some exceptions, is hardly more than mediocre, still the life o Campanian city had so many ramifications, extending to all parts of the ranean, to all periods of earlier history, and to all aspects and phases and the human individual, that one may constantly return there and as something new.

A glance at our Plate 25, Fig. 4 will show that if there ever w statue on the arched structure in question, the statue was a colossus so hug to dominate the Forum, and more than challenge comparison with the cult s in the Capitoline temple facing 3. It is inconceivable that Augustus would or that Tiberius would have tolerated, the erection of such a statue in Ital reigns: it was reserved for Nero and Domitian to assimilate themselves t outspoken a fashion.

body_text.text: The resemblance of our monument to an arch rather than a base has naturally been felt by earlier writers, e. g. iii, No. 6 (V. SPINAZZOLA, in AC. S., 1916, 429.450). These latter however are set at wider intervals, and have a greater breadth than depth; it is evident too from the vestiges in the wall that they served to support a wooden wardrobe, a portion of which is in fact represented by the cast which the excavators were able to make from the impression which it had left in the This hall of unusual plan has been explained either as a sloa poikile or as a market,
body_text.head_section: THE GREAT INSCRIPTION ON THE PAVEMENT OF THE FORUM.

body_text.text: and it has been suggested that grain or vegetables were sold there. The former of these two explanations is excluded by the consideration that the building is one of the few public edifices which were either begun or rebuilt from the ground after the earthquake of 63: it must therefore have been essential to. the public utility, not a purely decorative structure. Its orientation, with eight wide openings facing somewhat north of east, unfits it for a grain or vegetable market 3; while one would expect a hall for the sale of more valuable merchandise to be less exposed to the eyes and hands of the general public. And quite apart from this building Pompeii was well provided with markets and shops.
body_text.head_section: THE GREAT INSCRIPTION ON THE PAVEMENT OF THE FORUM.

body_text.text: I propose its identification as a school building, for which its location and plan would seem to adapt it admirably. Owing to its easterly exposure, it would be the warmest building on the Forum in the late mornings of Winter. We know that school was held in the Forum, from a Pompeian painting now in the Naples Museum, one of the series representing the life of the Forum 4, in which such a school is shown in operation. In the period immediately preceding the eruption, that is to say while our school building was in course of erection, school was held, apparently as a temiporary measure, in or near the edifice at the south-east corner of the Forum (E in plan), the I MAU, Pompeii, 2d ed., 87-89. The vaults have also been called a prison; of A. SOGLIANO, in N. S., 1900, 236-238; he concludes: Lasciando da parle qualsiasi congettura sulla destinazione cosi dei locali superiori come di quelli inferiori, trovo che la relazione da qualcuno ammessa fra i due piani dell'edificio non esiste per nulla, essendo l'un piano del tulto indipendente dall'altro. Mancando il rapporto topografico, viene necessariamente a mancare qualunque alUro rapporto.

He has in mind a southern or western exposure as especially undesirable for granaries etc.; but a vegetable market with easterly exposure would be at an equal disadvantage, as the vegetables would generally be brought in to the city and sold there in the morning.
body_text.head_section: THE GREAT INSCRIPTION ON THE PAVEMENT OF THE FORUM.

body_text.text: The identification as a grain market has been thought to find confirmation in the not far distant standard table of measures. But this dates in its original form from the Samnite period, and in its present adaptation from the earlier part of the reign of Augustus, and therefore has no connection with the structure urnder discussion; moreover, its purpose was not for use in connection with the actual transacting of business, but to serve for the standardizing of the merchants' measures. Before closing this article it is desirable to enter a word of caution wit the view held by some archaeologists as to the Pre-Roman Forum and the changes introduced in the plan by the Romans at the time that the colony was founded. As this theory involves a whole phase of the early history of Pompeii, it is necessary to quote it in some detail as it was developed by the late Abbe Thedenat 2:
body_text.head_section: THE GREAT INSCRIPTION ON THE PAVEMENT OF THE FORUM.

body_text.text: n Le Forum de Pompei occupa toujours une partie de l'emplacement oiu le voyons aujourd'hui. Ce fut d'abord une simple place entre quatre rues. On peut encore reconnaitre les limites de ce Forum primitif. La rue de l'Abondance et la rue della Marina, a ce temps4la, ne formaient qu'une seule voie qui, sans doute, etait la limite septentrionale de la place. A l'ouest, le Forum etait borne par une rue qui descend entre la basilique et le temple de Venus; au sud, par la rue qui passe devant la maison de Championnet et les Curies; a l'est, par la rue delle Scuole. Ces rues n'ont pas dQ changer car, parmi les maisons qui les bordent, il en est de tres anciennes. A la fois march& et Forum, la place etait plus longue que large; aussi, quand on construisit la basilique, c'est sur sa longueur qu'on prit le terrain necessaire.
body_text.head_section: THE GREAT INSCRIPTION ON THE PAVEMENT OF THE FORUM.

body_text.text: n Au li1 siecle avant notre ere, un questeur de Pompei, Vibius Popidius. fit regulariser la place et l'entoura d'un portique a deux etages..... " Tel etait l'etat du Forum quand les Romains entrerent a Pompei. Ils y trouverent donc un forum grec. Pour qui connait les usages des Romains, il est evident que le forum grec ne devait longtemps survivre a l'installation des colons envoyes par Sylla..... Aussit8t la colonie etablie, les Romains s'occuperent donc de transformer en forum romain le forum grec des Samnites. La grande place rectangulaire fut jalonnee au milieu des rues et des maisons qui recouvraient l'emplacement qu'on lui destina; on y fit entrer le Forum samnite; le lieu choisi pour elever le temple de Jupiter occupait l'extremite opposee; de telle sorte que le forum romain ne fut qu'un prolongement vers le nord du forum grec '.
body_text.head_section: THE GREAT INSCRIPTION ON THE PAVEMENT OF THE FORUM.

body_text.text: This theory, however attractive it may appear in the French savant's presentation, nevertheless must be rejected: it is unnecessary, and it is at variance with the evidence.
body_text.head_section: THE GREAT INSCRIPTION ON THE PAVEMENT OF THE FORUM.

body_text.text: There is no need to assume any violent modification of the general plan of the Forum, in fact all the evidence points toward a fair degree of continuity. The colonnade of Popidius, which antedates the Roman colony, occupies all the South end and the southern part of the eastern side, and on the western side there are traces of it almost to the northern extremity. The discovery of remains of dwelling houses under the central space of the Basilica (I in plan Fig. 1) 3 shows that the earlier Forum did not extend much further to the West than the present one, at least in its southern portion; moreover 1 MAU, Pompeji, 2d ed., 115 f. It has not been recognised however that this pavement contained a great inscription, in letters of bronze set into the limestone blocks, and running from the west to the east side of the Forum. Of this monumental inscription there survives in position only the cutting for the first letter, a Q, in a block of the pavement immediately to the East of the very large oblong statue base which is situated at about the middle of the west side of the Forum (see plan Fig. 1) 3. THE CURIA. (P1. 25, Fig. 1-3). The central one of the three halls at the south end of the Forum, wh unfinished at the time of the eruption (G in plan Fig. 1), has been traditio tified, by conjecture but with great probability, as the Curia '. A detail o struction may be adduced as confirming this identification and at the same time a passage in Vitruvius. Along the two sides exist what apparently wers to the bases of small columns set against the walls 2. (See P1. 25, Fig. 2). The would presumably have carried cornices breaking the flat surface of the walls in turn would have supported an upper order. This arrangement is in accor the precept of Vitruvius for the construction of a curia (V, ii): Aerarium, c foro sunt coniungenda, sed ita uti magnitudo (ac) symmetriae eorum foro r maxime quidem curia in primis est facienda ad dignitatem municipii sive civita terea praecingendi sunt parietes medii coronis ex intestino opere aut albario ad partem altitudinis. quae si non erunt, vox ibi disputantium elata in altitudinem non poterit esse audientibus. cum autem coronis praecincti parietes 'erunt, vox a rata, priusquam in czera elata dissipabitur, auribus eri1 intellecta.
